utterances: This is the Ingalls homestead, the land that Laura Ingalls Wilder's family of ""Little House on the Prairie"" fame finally settled on in the 1880s.

Seventeen-year-old Ann Poppin is teaching these city kids how to drive the covered wagon.
She loves her job, but she says sometimes she's afraid the tourists don't really understand pioneer life; they romanticize it.
I guess being a rural person and living on a farm, you kind of have a better understanding of what it's like to actually farm.

And so you can relate to these people that, you know, had to come out here and travel so many miles and struggle and struggle and struggle for hours on end just to get a crop in and then watch it, you know, burn up in the heat with no rain or, you know, watch grasshoppers devour it.
Poppin's family farm is about 12 miles from here, a thousand acres of crops and 120 head of cattle, and she loves it.

But she says sometimes the government seems to respond to the ideas that city people have about rural farming life rather than what the farmers themselves need, like with regulations on how many animals can be kept in a feed lot, for instance.

And, Poppin says, even for pioneer Charles Ingalls, Laura's dad, government was part of life.

The Ingalls had to live on this land for five years, till and sow at least 10 acres every season and plant the required number of trees for that windbreak.
